sub_topic: Show that every group of order 32 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C32, the dihedral group D16, or one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.
message_1: Prove that a group G of order 32 is isomorphic to one of the following groups: C32, D16, or one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32 by identifying its specific properties and structure.
message_2:
To prove that a group G of order 32 is isomorphic to one of the following groups: C32, D16, or one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32, we will use the Sylow theorems and the structure of p-groups.

First, note that 32 = 2^5, so G is a group of order p^5, where p = 2. By the Sylow theorems, we know that the number of Sylow 2-subgroups of G is equal to 1 mod 2 and divides 1 (since 32 is a power of 2). Therefore, there is a unique Sylow 2-subgroup of G, which we will denote by P.

Since P is the unique Sylow 2-subgroup of G, it is normal in G. Now, we will analyze the structure of P. Since P is a group of order 2^5, it is a p-group, and by the structure theorem for p-groups, we know that P has a non-trivial center, i.e., |Z(P)| > 1. The possible orders for Z(P) are 2, 4, 8, 16, and 32.

Case 1: |Z(P)| = 32
In this case, P is abelian and isomorphic to C32. Since P is normal in G and G has order 32, G is isomorphic to C32.

Case 2: |Z(P)| = 16
In this case, P is an extension of Z(P) by a group of order 2. Since Z(P) is abelian, P is also abelian and isomorphic to C16 × C2. Since P is normal in G and G has order 32, G is isomorphic to C16 × C2.

Case 3: |Z(P)| = 8
In this case, P is an extension of Z(P) by a group of order 4. Since Z(P) is abelian, P is either abelian and isomorphic to C8 × C4 or non-abelian and isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32. If P is abelian, then G is isomorphic to C8 × C4. If P is non-abelian, then G is isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.

Case 4: |Z(P)| = 4
In this case, P is an extension of Z(P) by a group of order 8. Since Z(P) is abelian, P is either abelian and isomorphic to C4 × C8 or non-abelian and isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32. If P is abelian, then G is isomorphic to C4 × C8. If P is non-abelian, then G is isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.

Case 5: |Z(P)| = 2
In this case, P is an extension of Z(P) by a group of order 16. Since Z(P) is abelian, P is either abelian and isomorphic to C2 × C16 or non-abelian and isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32. If P is abelian, then G is isomorphic to C2 × C16. If P is non-abelian, then G is isomorphic to one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.

In summary, a group G of order 32 is isomorphic to one of the following groups: C32, D16 (which is isomorphic to C16 × C2), or one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.
